related_questions.question: How do you write an executive summary?
related_questions.title: AI Overview
list: Purpose: . Opens in new tabDetermine the specific goals of the document and the message you want to convey. An executive summary should answer key questions that the document addresses.
Audience: . Opens in new tabConsider who will be reading the summary and tailor the content and language accordingly.
Start with a strong hook: Begin with a captivating opening that grabs the reader's attention and introduces the topic.
State the problem or need: Briefly describe the issue or opportunity that the document addresses.
Outline the solution: Summarize the key recommendations, actions, or proposed solutions presented in the document.
Highlight key findings and benefits: Briefly mention the main results, conclusions, or outcomes of the report.
Conclude with a call to action: If appropriate, provide a clear call to action or indicate the next steps.
Be concise and clear: Use simple, direct language and avoid jargon or technical terms that may not be familiar to the reader.
Focus on the main points: Include only the most important information and avoid unnecessary details or background information.
Use an active voice: Write in an active voice to make the language more engaging and impactful.
Keep it short: Executive summaries are typically one to two pages long, depending on the length of the original document.
Ensure it can stand alone: The executive summary should be understandable even if the reader hasn't read the full report.
Proofread carefully: Check for any errors in grammar, spelling, and punctuation.
Ensure clarity and accuracy: Make sure the summary accurately reflects the content of the full document.
Get feedback: Ask a colleague to review the summary for clarity and completeness.

related_questions.question: What are the 5 components of an executive summary?
related_questions.snippet: An executive summary has six key components. These components are the subject matter, background problem, range of investigation, methods of analysis, findings or issues, and finally the arguments, conclusions, and recommendations.
